verses.text: Jesus spoke to them again in parables, saying:
verses.comment: This verse introduces another parable from Jesus, continuing His teaching ministry. The use of parables is a method Jesus often used to communicate deep spiritual truths while also revealing and concealing meaning depending on the listener's openness.

verses.text: "The kingdom of heaven is like a king who arranged a wedding banquet for his son."
verses.comment: Jesus uses the imagery of a royal wedding feast to illustrate the kingdom of God. The king symbolizes God the Father, and His son foreshadows Christ. The banquet recalls Messianic prophecies of the feast in Isaiah and the Psalms, showing both a literal and spiritual fulfillment.

verses.text: He sent out his servants to call those who had been invited to the banquet, but they would not come.
verses.comment: The servants symbolize the prophets and ministers of God. The refusal of the invited guests reflects Israel's repeated rejection of God's messengers.

verses.text: Again, he sent other servants, saying, 'Tell those who are invited, “Look, I have prepared my dinner; my oxen and fattened cattle are slaughtered, and everything is ready. Come to the wedding banquet.”'
verses.comment: The king's persistence shows God's enduring mercy and patience. The feast prepared represents the fullness of salvation, the readiness of God's grace towards all who will come.

verses.text: But they paid no attention and went off, one to his farm, another to his business.
verses.comment: Here, worldly concerns take precedence over the king's invitation, symbolizing how many are preoccupied with temporal things and neglect the call to eternal life.

verses.text: The rest seized his servants, mistreated them, and killed them.
verses.comment: The violence against the king's servants refers to the persecution of prophets and, later, of the apostles and followers of Christ.

verses.text: The king was enraged. He sent his armies, destroyed those murderers, and burned their city.
verses.comment: This foreshadows the judgment which befell Jerusalem in AD 70, but also has spiritual meaning: persistent rejection of grace leads to judgment.

verses.text: Then he said to his servants, 'The wedding banquet is ready, but those who were invited were not worthy.'
verses.comment: Because of repeated rejection, the original guests are considered 'not worthy,' opening the invitation to others. This shows the transition of God's invitation from Israel to the Gentiles.

verses.text: 'Go therefore to the crossroads, and invite everyone you find to the wedding feast.'
verses.comment: Salvation is now freely offered to all, both Jews and Gentiles. The universal invitation points to the Church’s mission to evangelize every nation.

verses.text: So the servants went out into the streets and gathered everyone they found, both evil and good. And the wedding hall was filled with guests.
verses.comment: The inclusivity of the call—regardless of moral status—shows the transformative grace of God. Yet, there are still expectations for those invited, hinted at in the coming verses.

verses.text: But when the king came in to see the guests, he noticed a man there who was not wearing wedding clothes.
verses.comment: Wedding garments symbolize the righteousness and sanctification expected of those in God’s kingdom. Admission is open, but transformation is required.

verses.text: He said to him, 'Friend, how did you get in here without wedding clothes?' The man was speechless.
verses.comment: No one can enter the wedding feast without being properly clothed—spiritually speaking, adorned in grace. The man’s silence suggests he had no excuse for his state.

verses.text: Then the king said to his servants, 'Bind him hand and foot, throw him outside into the outer darkness, where there will be weeping and grinding of teeth.'
verses.comment: This describes the consequences of refusing to be changed by God’s grace. This outer darkness is a consistent image of spiritual separation and judgment.

verses.text: "For many are called, but few are chosen."
verses.comment: Many receive the invitation (calling), but only those who respond in obedience and are clothed in righteousness are admitted. The interplay of grace and human response is highlighted here.

verses.text: Then the Pharisees went and plotted how they might trap Him in His words.
verses.comment: Jesus' teaching provokes opposition from religious leaders who seek to undermine His authority.

verses.text: They sent their disciples to Him along with the Herodians, saying, "Teacher, we know You are true and teach the way of God truthfully. You do not care about anyone's opinion, for You are not swayed by appearances."
verses.comment: Their praise is insincere, intended to flatter and trap Jesus. The alliance between Pharisees and Herodians is unusual, showing their desperation.

verses.text: "Tell us, then, what You think: Is it lawful to pay taxes to Caesar, or not?"
verses.comment: This question is a political trap. A ‘yes’ answer risks alienating nationalists; a ‘no’ answer risks Roman retribution.

verses.text: But Jesus, knowing their evil intent, said, "Why are you testing Me, you hypocrites?"
verses.comment: Jesus sees through outward appearances and discerns people's hearts, asserting His divine knowledge.

verses.text: "Show Me the coin used for the tax." So they brought Him a denarius.
verses.comment: The denarius bore the image of Caesar and was the common Roman coin used to pay the poll-tax.

verses.text: "Whose image and inscription is this?" He asked them.
verses.comment: The word 'image' recalls humanity being made in the image of God (Genesis 1:27).

verses.text: "Caesar's," they replied. Then He said to them, "So give to Caesar what is Caesar's, and to God what is God's."
verses.comment: Jesus distinguished between earthly and heavenly obligations. This answers their trap and lays a foundation for the harmony between civil responsibility and ultimate allegiance to God.

verses.text: When they heard this, they marveled, and leaving Him, they went away.
verses.comment: Jesus’ answer astonished both parties, revealing His divine wisdom and authority.

verses.text: That same day, some Sadducees, who say there is no resurrection, came to Him and asked,
verses.comment: Sadducees denied the resurrection, angels, and spirits—distinguishing themselves from Pharisees.

verses.text: “Teacher, Moses said, 'If a man dies without having children, his brother must marry the widow and raise up offspring for him.’”
verses.comment: They cite the law of levirate marriage, showing reliance on the Torah, and implying a supposed absurdity within resurrection belief.

verses.text: Now there were seven brothers among us. The first married and died, and, having no offspring, left his wife to his brother.
verses.comment: This hypothetical scenario is designed to mock the concept of resurrection.

verses.text: The same happened to the second, and the third, down to the seventh.
verses.comment: Their story reduces belief in resurrection to an absurdity, according to their view.

verses.text: Last of all, the woman also died.
verses.comment: The scenario is finally completed—setting up their question about the resurrection.

verses.text: So at the resurrection, whose wife will she be of the seven? For they all had married her.
verses.comment: Their question tests whether Jesus’ theology aligns coherently with the Mosaic law and logic.

verses.text: Jesus replied, "You are mistaken, because you do not know the Scriptures or the power of God."
verses.comment: Jesus affirms the reality of the resurrection and the power of God beyond human logic, referencing scriptural support later.

verses.text: For at the resurrection people will neither marry nor be given in marriage but will be like the angels in heaven.
verses.comment: Earthly institutions such as marriage do not persist in the resurrected state. Relationships are transformed in the presence of God, affirming the dignity and personal identity of the human soul.

verses.text: But as for the resurrection of the dead, have you not read what God said to you,
verses.comment: Jesus appeals directly to Scripture’s authority, challenging the Sadducees with the Torah itself, which they accept.

verses.text: 'I am the God of Abraham, the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob.' He is not the God of the dead, but of the living."
verses.comment: God’s covenant is living; Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob are alive to Him. This is a high Christological moment: Christ interprets Scripture authoritatively as only God can.

verses.text: And when the crowds heard this, they were astonished at His teaching.
verses.comment: Jesus’ teaching confounds both religious leaders and crowds, demonstrating His divine wisdom and authority.

verses.text: But when the Pharisees heard that He had silenced the Sadducees, they gathered together.
verses.comment: Jesus’ triumph over the Sadducees’ argument leads the Pharisees to regroup and attempt another challenge.

verses.text: One of them, a lawyer, asked Him a question to test Him:
verses.comment: The legal expert seeks to trap Jesus in a theological debate. Lawyers were scholars of Mosaic law.

verses.text: "Teacher, which commandment in the Law is the greatest?"
verses.comment: The Law (Torah) contains 613 commandments, and identifying the greatest one was much debated.

verses.text: Jesus replied, "'You shall love the Lord your God with all your heart, with all your soul, and with all your mind.'
verses.comment: Jesus quotes the Shema (Deuteronomy 6:5), foundational to Israel’s faith—worship directed totally to God.

verses.text: This is the greatest and first commandment.
verses.comment: Total love of God is the foundation and summary of all true religion. This highlights authentic faith as relational, not just legal.

verses.text: And the second is like it: 'You shall love your neighbor as yourself.'
verses.comment: Love of neighbor is inseparable from love of God. True love for others flows from love for God, hinting at the unity of faith and works.

verses.text: On these two commandments hang all the Law and the Prophets."
verses.comment: Jesus presents love as the summary principle of all God’s revelation. Obedience, faith, and the moral law converge here, showing how doctrinal and practical life are united.

verses.text: While the Pharisees were gathered together, Jesus asked them,
verses.comment: Jesus now turns the tables, seizing the initiative in debate with the Pharisees.

verses.text: "What do you think about the Christ? Whose son is He?" They said to Him, "The son of David."
verses.comment: The title 'Son of David' refers to the Messianic prophecy of a ruler from David's line. Jesus is about to deepen this understanding.

verses.text: He said to them, "How then does David in the Spirit call Him 'Lord,' saying:
verses.comment: Jesus affirms the inspiration of Scripture and David’s prophetic role, highlighting both the Holy Spirit's work and Christ’s divinity.

verses.text: 'The LORD said to my Lord, "Sit at My right hand until I put Your enemies under Your feet"?'
verses.comment: This is a high-point of Christology. The Messiah, though descended from David, is called 'Lord.' Sitting at God's right hand indicates sharing God's authority and divinity.

verses.text: If then David calls Him 'Lord,' how is He his son?"
verses.comment: Jesus exposes the incomplete understanding of Messiah. The Messiah is both David's descendant and his Lord—pointing to His divine and human natures (see also John 1:1-14).

verses.text: No one was able to answer Him a word, nor from that day did anyone dare to question Him any more.
verses.comment: Jesus' divine wisdom silences His adversaries, establishing His authority. This section shows Christ’s power and knowledge, which foreshadow the foundation and unity of His Church, centered on divine truth revealed through Him.
